awd_titl_txt: EAGER: The RNA Landscape as defined by RNA binding proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
Grains are a major staple for the world’s population as they provide more than 51% of the world’s caloric intake.  As the world population is projected to reach 9.8 billion by 2050, more food will have to be produced than ever before.  Although considerable effort is directed at understanding how genes are regulated and transcribed into RNAs in the nucleus during grain development, very little is known about the cellular events that control the translation of these RNAs into protein in the cytoplasm. Previous efforts from this laboratory have demonstrated that grain RNAs are not immediately translated into protein when they exit the nucleus.  Instead, they form large particles, which are transported along several different pathways to the cortical region, a site located underneath the plasma membrane that surrounds the cell.  Studies supported by this grant will attempt to identify the mechanism by which these large RNA particles are formed and whether RNA species that code for proteins related by function are co-assembled into these particles.  Results from these studies may lead to new insights into the mechanisms that control the utilization and conversion of sugars into starch and of amino acids into protein reserves and, thereby, aid in efforts to increase grain productivity and yields.

The transport and localization of mRNAs to discrete intracellular sites in plant cells and their subsequent translation or processing are dependent on multiple assemblies of RNA binding proteins (RBPs).  These RBPs, which recognize specific cis-regulatory sequences on the RNA, play multiple post-transcriptional roles in the nucleus and cytoplasm.  As nearly all RBPs work in concert with other RBPs and accessory proteins, a deeper understanding of how these RBP complexes are formed and the nature of their RNA targets is essential before their function in post-transcriptional processes can be appreciated.  While many plant RBPs that mediate RNA localization and downstream processes have been identified, information on their organization into multi-RBP complexes is just beginning to emerge.  By contrast, nothing is known on the RNA binding sites and the nature of the mRNAs bound by plant RBP complexes.  While the technologies, seCLIP and RIPiT-Seq, are routinely used to identify the properties of RBPs from human cell lines, their utility in identifying the RNA targets of individual and interacting pairs of plant RBPs remains problematic.  As a proof of concept, this project will establish the experimental protocols for routine identification of RNA targets by four RBPs that co-assemble into two distinct multiprotein complexes.  Specifically, the project will define the RNA sequences bound by the four RBPs using seCLIP and the mRNA species bound by different combinations of RBPs using RIPiT-Seq.  Results from this study may provide evidence that mRNAs related by function, cytological location, or cellular fate are bound by the same RBPs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Past studies supported by NSF identified four RNA binding proteins (RBPs A, I, J, and K), which recognized specific RNA sequences (zipcodes) responsible for targeting the rice prolamine storage protein mRNAs to a specific subdomain of the endoplasmic reticulum.  Based on a combination of co-immunoprecipitation, yeast 2-hybrid, and bimolecular fluorescence complementation approaches, evidence was obtained that these zipcode RBPs comprise a larger protein interactome network where various combinations of these zipcode RBPs co-assemble to form multi-RBP complexes to mediate post-transcriptional regulation.  Such RBP complexes presumably confer the targeting specificity of RNAs to specific intracellular locations where they translated, stabilized, subjected to mRNA decay, processed by RISCs, or associated with P-bodies and stress granules. Moreover, analysis of the mRNAs that are extracellularly displaced in rice mutant lines defective in mRNA localization suggests that mRNAs related by function, cytological location, and/or cellular fate may possibly be co-transported together as regulons.  

The goals of this project were to obtain direct experimental evidence that different combinations of RBPs co-assemble to form diverse sets of multi-protein complexes, which bind specific mRNA species. This will be accomplished by using seCLIP, a UV-crosslinking, immunoprecipitation technique that identifies the RNA site bound by a specific RBP.  After UV exposure of developing rice seed peels, consisting of aleurone and 4-6 layers of outer subaluerone-endosperm cell layers, to crosslink RBPs to bound RNAs, the samples were processed using the seCLIP protocol with the exception that the suggested RNase treatment step was removed as the yield of RNA-RBP complexes was insufficient to generate sufficient cDNA for sequencing.

A total of 500, 615, 979, and 462 significant peaks (crosslink sites) were identified in various mRNAs in at least two replicates for RBP-A, I, J or K, respectively.  Many of UV crosslink sites bound by one RBP were also bound by one or several other RBPs, indicating that the UV crosslink site was bound by RBPs organized as multi-RBP complexes and that different combinations of RBPs recognized different mRNAs. For instance, 232 different mRNAs were bound by RBPs A, I, J and K at the same mRNA crosslink site.   In addition 119, 9, 27, 16, 65, 4, 29, 193, 16, and 39 RNAs were bound by combinations of AIJ, AIK, AJK, AI, AJ, AK, IJK, IJ, IK, and JK, respectively.  Nearly all of RBP-I (614 out of a total of 615) and most (472 out of a total of 500) RBP-A were found to bind to mRNAs as multi-RBP complexes.  The authenticity of our results were validated by the finding that RBPs A, I, J and K bound to 5 different prolamine mRNAs at the same crosslink site located adjacent to the prolamine 3’UTR zipcode, the cis-determinant required for targeting prolamine mRNAs to the specific locations on the cortical endoplasmic reticulum.

Of the various RBP combinations, AIJK, AIJ and IJ multi-RBP complexes were the major activities as they bound 232, 119, and 193 different mRNAs, respectively.  The nature of the mRNAs bound by these three multi-RBP complexes was not random and tended to fall into specific classes.  In particular, these multi-protein complexes bound to mRNAs that code for proteins involved in the secretory pathway, nucleic acid processes (e.g. transcription. DNA and RNA binding), signal transduction pathways, and ubiquitin-related metabolism.  AIJK was the only multi-RBP complex of the three that bound mRNAs for storage proteins and starch-related enzymes.  These results support the view that various RBP combinations recognize mRNAs associated with specific biological roles in plant cells.

Although considerable information has been generated over the years on how plant genes are controlled at the transcriptional and post-transcriptional levels, we are just beginning to understand the role of specific RBPs in these processes.  Our results indicate that RBPs do not work singularly but in concert with other RBPs.  Moreover, the results support the view that combinations of RBPs bind mRNAs that code for proteins sharing common function.

In addition to obtaining new insights in plant RNA biology and establishing seCLIP as useful experimental technique for the identification of mRNAs specifically recognized by plant RBPs, this project enhanced the career development and research experience of a senior researcher and postdoctoral research associate.  During the project, the senior researcher was successful in gaining a faculty position.  The succeeding  postdoctoral research associate acquired new experimental technology that will be useful in her future research in plant biology.

 


Last Modified: 01/07/2025
Modified by: Thomas W Okita
